project.title: All About Red-Eyed Tree Frogs in Scratch

challenge.title: Stitch a Stuffed Animal or Pillow
Create a Repo on GitHub
challenge.description: Many people use Github.com to create projects, aka "repos", and make them open source. This way everyone can benefit from the work. Join Github.com and create and edit your first repo!

challenge.title: Fork a Repo on GitHub
challenge.description: To contribute to a project you'll need to first fork (aka copy) the project files to your GitHub account. Fork DIY's open-sourcerer repo and upload a screenshot of it from your GitHub page.

challenge.title: Push Changes in Bash
challenge.description: When you've changed a file locally, you'll want to push those changes to the servers at Github.com. Use Bash to push your local changes to your fork on Github.com. Take a screenshot of Bash when the push goes through.

challenge.title: Submit a Pull Request on GitHub
Make a Travel Map
challenge.description: On an Atlas or Map find all of the places you've been or want to visit. Add a pin to these locations to create a log of your travels.

challenge.title: Map your Land
challenge.description: Draw a map of your bedroom, house, or neighborhood. Try to include all the landmarks that are important to you. It helps to get a view from high up  – you can use another map as a reference.

challenge.title: Make a Data Visualization Map
challenge.description: Weather maps, traffic maps, election maps, populaton maps – these are ways of showing data geo-spatially. You could collect your own data of where people travel in your house, or where your bus line travels, and map it.

comment.raw:
These are the trips I took in 2012! I'm using a vertical timeline in the middle of the map to show what month the trip happened in.  

I created the map in Adobe Illustrator, starting with a free vector file of the USA from wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Blank_maps

 

I invoked some creative freedom and made Argentina an island close to New Orleans so that they'd all fit in one image nicely :smile: It's not really, truly located as shown! :wink:
comment.html:
These are the trips I took in 2012! I'm using a vertical timeline in the middle of the map to show what month the trip happened in.  

I created the map in Adobe Illustrator, starting with a free vector file of the USA from wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Blank_maps

I invoked some creative freedom and made Argentina an island close to New Orleans so that they'd all fit in one image nicely  It's not really, truly located as shown!

comment.raw:
I made this map of Boston when I lived there for 3 years. The full map is here: 
http://jlord.us/work/boston-map/

I created it in Adobe Illustrator by starting with a screenshot of a Google Map of Boston and then creating new layers on top of that where I traced the boundaries of the neighborhoods and then colored it as I liked it, eventually deleting the first screenshot layer.
comment.html:
I made this map of Boston when I lived there for 3 years. The full map is here:  http://jlord.us/work/boston-map/

I created it in Adobe Illustrator by starting with a screenshot of a Google Map of Boston and then creating new layers on top of that where I traced the boundaries of the neighborhoods and then colored it as I liked it, eventually deleting the first screenshot layer.

comment.raw:
You can see the web map here: 
http://tiles.mapbox.com/jllord/map/whereIbeen#5.00/31.641/-90.080 

There is a different color dot for each month of the year.

 got data about my locations from using Foursquare and OpenPaths.cc
I designed the map in Tilemill: http://mapbox.com/tilemill/

challenge.title: Weave
challenge.description: Woven materials are everywhere. Most fabrics are made from woven strands, as are hi-tech materials like super-strong carbon and fiberglass mesh. Start out with a Hair Braid or Bracelet until you’re ready to tackle a Hand Woven Rug or a Wicker Chair.

comment.raw: Thanks! They're really fun to make because you don't need a pattern, you just make it up as you go.
comment.html: Thanks! They're really fun to make because you don't need a pattern, you just make it up as you go.

challenge.title: Play a Co-Op Game with Friends
Make a How To
challenge.description: A simple picture of your finished project can inspire other makers, but to actually teach them to make what you've made, you'll need to make a How To. Create a step-by-step guide using photos with captions, or just shoot video and talk about what you're doing.

challenge.title: Play a Co-Op Game with Friends
challenge.description: Co-Op Games allow multiple players to work together to succeed in the game. You can provide cover, maneuver over obstacles, share items, and discuss strategy. To solve this Challenge, take a screen shot or video of you and your team in action.

challenge.title: Play a Co-Op Game with Friends
Play a Co-Op Game with Friends
Plant a Seed
challenge.description: Raise a seedling in a tray until it is large and strong enough to transplant. Start it off indoors and take special care of it before it goes in the ground.

challenge.title: Create a Button Kit
challenge.description: Buttons, arrows, menus, sliders and banners all help us navigate a site. This kit of components is reused all over a website. Print out the template, and draw your own set of website components. Then cut them out and rearrange them.

challenge.title: Gather Website Inspiration
challenge.description: Visit your favorite websites. Are they beautiful? Easy to use? Are there little details that you love in particular? To solve this challenge, upload screenshots of your favorite pieces of web design inspiration.
